researchIntrest.title: Remapping metabolism upon DNA damage
researchIntrest.description: Problems with DNA repair pathways have been observed in cardiac failure patients. Additionally, recent data suggests that pediatric patients treated with genotoxic agents, develop disabling or life-threatening age- related diseases compared to their siblings.

researchIntrest.title: Decoding the role of DNA in post-mitotic cells
researchIntrest.description: The central hypothesis that guides our research is that stochastic, endogenous nuclear DNA damage alters cellular and metabolic programs, leading to progression of multiple, age- related degenerative diseases.

researchIntrest.title: Defining your composite 'biological' age
researchIntrest.description: Although, one’s chronological age maybe the same (the age that you calculate from your birth certificate), two people who are 65, rarely feel the same.

team.name: Aditi Gurkar
team.title: Principal Investigator
team.Description: Aditi U. Gurkar is an Assistant Professor in the Aging Institute, Division of Geriatric Medicine at the University of Pittsburgh. I believe that aging is one true mystery that surrounds us. Aging is inescapable and unfortunately the principal risk factor for a number of diseases including cancer, heart disease and Alzheimer disease (AD).

team.name: Shruthi Hamsanathan
team.title: Research Scientist
team.Description: My research interest has always been towards understanding complex biological mechanisms. I am particularly fascinated by transport mechanisms occurring at biological membranes. I find this as an interesting challenge for a cell, as it should maintain the membrane integrity while it transports proteins or other biomolecules across the membrane for survival.

team.name: Lucile Marchal
team.Description: I have always been interested in biology and had the chance to study biochemistry, cellular biology and physiology at the University of Besançon (France) during my B.S. equivalent. I then joined the bioengineering program of the Polytech'Nice Engineering School of the University of Nice (France), where I learned more about biotechnologies and pharmacology.

team.Description: Austin has been in the lab for a year now and works on developing tools to induce DNA damage at specific sites in the nuclear genome.

team.name: Roshan Karthikappallil

team.Description: Roshan is a Med student at Oxford and interested in how different types of DNA damage contributes to healthspan and aging pathologies.

testimonials.name: ELLA SIEFKEN
testimonials.title: High School Summer Student: Early acceptance at University of Chicago
testimonials.smallDesc: Working and researching in the Gurkar Lab brought much more than bench experience.
testimonials.description: The researchers I worked with were patient, skilled, and extremely fun, and they conveyed the lab’s meticulous and original strategy for exploring the links between aging and DNA damage with unmatched enthusiasm. I loved my time here, and can’t wait to see where the research goes!

testimonials.name: Roshan Karthikappallil
testimonials.title: Summer undergraduate Laidlaw Scholar, Oxford University
testimonials.smallDesc: Over 8 weeks this summer, I worked on an independent research project in the Gurkar Lab at the Aging Institute.
testimonials.description: This was my first experience of research, and so having Dr Gurkar as my supervisor made all the difference in the world. She led me through the stages of planning out my project, data collection, and even data analysis, and the skills and knowledge which I gained from my time at the lab have been absolutely invaluable back at university in Oxford. Dr Gurkar and the whole team at the Gurkar lab are all lovely people and were very enthusiastic in welcoming me to Pittsburgh and to their lab. They were all very happy to help me with the details of my lab work and the different assays which I carried out, and I am really happy that I had the chance to know everyone there over my summer! Working at the Aging Institute, I had the opportunity to listen to fascinating talks from experts in the field of aging, on subjects such as novel senolytic drugs and telomere biology. However, my most memorable experiences of the summer included the time our lab spent together, including our lab picnic in Oakland at the end of summer, weekly lab meetings and journal club (always sure to feature a sweet treat!), and the lab potluck we had right before I left. I would thoroughly recommend the Gurkar lab to any students who would like to gain research experience in a fun and welcoming environment.
